Early Access Review

This is a great game on mobile, and the PC version is looking good. I'm pretty sure it will be able to stand its own as a PC game as well.

The comparison to Hearthstone is inevitable as the game borrows heavily from it and is now competing in the same markets, so I will make it a lot, since I guess many people have experienced HS.

The game is like Hearthstone done right. No RNG bs effects on cards. Fast iteration on card balance (no patrons ruining the game for months). And tons more options for how you use your units thanks to the fact that you have to move them on a chess-like board. All in all a fantastic mix of card strategy and positional tactics.

The F2P model is very good (basically the same as in HS) and you can get any cards by just playing the game. There is no pressure to buy stuff. Even the scenarios are price accessible (unlike HS)

Cons: the artwork is very nice and colorful (if you like that kind of fun-light style) but not very consistent. Unit drawings vary in style (shading, outline color), and unit animations are kind of stiff looking. But this kind of superficial, as the game plays great and looks good in general.

Turn-based strategy games require a high degree of balance to maintain even a basic level of enjoyability. Incorporating cards, this game ran a particular risk in that it could easily become heavily P2W, require too much time to attain necessary game elements, and/or botch its game board element by way of card abilities.

This game avoided all of the vices.

Cards and Castles upholds the virtues of its genre(s). As of its most recent patch, it is highly balanced and increasingly so. It lets you jump in head first without stripping the player of all merit-based reward. And perhaps most importantly: The game is FUN. With my first 100 hours of gameplay, I can safely say that the game has lots of steam left in it. You can  enjoy this game in passing moments via Asynchronous play, in short sessions to test new decks via friendly mode, or grind it out over time toward the heralded Rank 1 in ranked mode. Each option grants the full Cards and Castles experience in its own way.

I look forward to continued improvements. Slight bugs persist, but they are addressed quickly. Connection issues have improved rapidly. Never before have I messaged about slight issues and had the lead game developer personally respond about the status of the fix toward the issues I had brought to light.

This is the work of people who know what they are doing and anyone would be wise to jump in early and grow alongside the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mini review. Given the nature of the genre, these are my early thoughts.

Picked this up in the recent Bundle Stars Crazy Loot Bundle. Not expecting much I booted it up and was pleasantly surprised in both the depth and scale of the game.

Cards and Castles is a crazy mash up between Hearthstone / Hero Academy and dollop of Chess. I’m fairly new to all these collectible card games and count myself a novice at best, when it comes to the strategy involved in creating decks etc. The tutorial scenario shows you the ropes, as to the basic ruleset and gameplay flow.

Instead of a static board like Hearthstone, the playfield is much like a rectangle chess board with each player's castle positioned at each end. You spent gold to place units on the board and then move them towards your opponent. As in Chess, units have various movement attributes. Extra game mechanics are added with units also having different stats health / attack points. You have spells and static building which add yet more buffs.

I love the artstyle of the game. The 5 different factions all have character and kind of remind me of Kingdom Rush. The music is fairly generic squeezebox medieval type tackle.

Given the size of the Bit Mass team, they should have no hope competing against the behemoth that is Blizzard, in any kind of genre. C&C may not have the polish, but it adds something fresh to mix which is movement / placement of units / buildings. It's a very potent and addictive cocktail of strategy goodness.

I’ve only put in 7+ hours, but I can see myself playing a lot more. To have a hearthstone-esk game on Steam is great and considering what I paid for the game, I’d recommend it to any fan of CCG’s.

Early Access Review

I LOVE this game. It's easy to pick up but hard to master. It's a card building game that you simply can't put down.
Earn cards by reaching certain levels or defeating certain enemies. Buy packs if that's something you're interested in. It offers a multiplayer mode and it's a hopping place. I haven't waiting more than a minute for an oppenent at all times of day and night. You can also enter tournaments, play scenarios, or invite your friends to a hearty battle. It has a good selection to choose from regarding game play.

What I really like about this game though is that I'm not stuck with the deck I built. I can go in and edit it or build a completely new deck AND keep my old one if I want. Combinations seem endless and I've spent so much time trying to build the perfect deck. I haven't succeeded yet but I'll let you know when I do.

All in all I do so recommend this game if you like tons of fun mixed into your strategy games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hearthstone, you've probably seen that pass back and forth in the reviews here and that's because it plays like that but not completely. They added another element in here that just spices up the gameplay a bit more and makes you think about how you play your cards and how you make your moves. It's exactly for that reason that I find it more enjoyable.

One of the best things for me with this game is that it's 'alive' and what I mean with that is when you play hearthstone you just sit and watch how your card jumps ontop of another card. It really feels like I'm playing a card game face to face with literally nothing interesting happening on the screen. Cards and Castles doesn't have that. The characters you play are on the screen, they move and interact with the others. It just feels more like a game to me and the simple yet cute artstyle is exactly what I love about it.

I tried several games like this that share the genre but the problem that I have with it is that: Most of it has lore or things that I'm not aware of. Hearthstone is being used as example here yet again. It's tied in with the WoW lore and while I find the games of this genre simple to play because you understand what you have to do, I'm not drawn to WoW so I miss a huge part of the excitement of familiar characters and places. Same with Magic the Gathering games. This game doesn't have that though and that's exactly what I need. I can just pick it up and play without having to go deep into lore.

Fun, simple and addicting. Finally a game of this genre I can enjoy without too much thinking and lucky lucky I can use my account for a mobile device and play on the train as well.

It's cute, simple and addictive. And just packs a little more interaction than one would expect from a card game like this.

It's a good game, but I'm one of the most active players (,at least in terms of forum participance), so take my words with a grain of salt.

Gameplay: It's good. You play on a grid-based board, and your pawns are unit cards that you deploy. Plays a lot like other CCGs, but the board differentiates the gameplay enough from the others.

Graphics: Cartoony and kinda comical. I like it, you might like it you might not. The card arts are beautiful, the sprite arts are decent.

Business: Probably disappointing. There has been a lot of back and forth with some of the content and pricing (the single player DLC (and the card rewards) which costs 45$ or months of grinding has been moved to the packs, making it kinda free). Overall, get the game, it's free now.

reviewText: This game is a cash grab.\n\nWhile possessing a relatively entertaining premise, this game is typical of the free to play (pay to win) genre. Though polished in appearance, passable graphics can't hide the basic nature of the game. The in game points can buy only one item in the shop, and at an excessive cost. The same points are also needed to unlock the almost entirely absent one player portion of the game, and with the primary method to getting more of these points winning pvp matches that are completely lacking in balancing, it is something that can take you a few hours to achieve. Compare this to the points purchased with -actual- currency which will give buyers a head start on anyone that was looking for a free (and fun) time killer. Not to mention the 10:1 presence of items purchasable with the cash currency, compared to the 'free' points (which themselves can be bought with real money). In part due to its recent launch, the game will have you waiting a while when trying to find an opponent for the pvp matches, not that it matters since once you get into a match ranked or non your odds of standing a chance are directly dependent on your cash investment for 4/5ths of those matches. This game should have stayed in testing a good while longer to flesh it out more and make it a fun game instead of a shameful cash grab that has visibly more time invested in how to get you to pay than in how to get you to have fun. It is free to play so you don't risk anything other than time, but for me at least it is time I could have better spent elsewhere.

reviewText:
At the time of writing this review. I'm a brand new player who just started a couple days ago. I only have about 18 hours in and I sunk 10 dollars in for the hell of it because I'm very much enjoying the game. I bought the Warlock campaign and a beginner only 5 booster pack bundle. I've completed the first two parts of the Warlock campaign and I'm currently stuck on the Open Mind scenario in part three. Wether it's because I'm bad or not I'm unsure, but I feel it's because I lack the deck building ability and cards I need. I've completed both The Ancient Hero and Tournament campaigns with minimal effort just took trial and error to learn the ropes. I also did my first free tournament and got utterly and completely trashed (as expected)

Now that my history is out of the way, I can safely say this is a GOOD game with a couple glaring flaws in my opinion. I believe shop costs are perfectly fine. As long as you do your quests and wind a few matches a day you can build up plenty of points to purchase packs and the non special campaigns. Though at the pace I'm at I highly doubt i will be playing any ranked at all for a long time unless if i were to drop a significant amount of money to get to the point where I can build a solid deck I'm super comfortable with. Though I will say this the game is very well balanced as far as I can tell. It's not like you can't win with economy decks but if the person is plain better than you and has plenty of good cards you don't stand a chance. The game is mostly skill and it should be. The factions are creative and the combinations you can make are plentyful, though I don't know the metagame because I've mostly been experimenting on my own. I've found comfort in a Crusader/Warlock deck the most so far.

As for flaws. The game is, I feel, very beginner unfriendly towards crafting. When required cards cost at least 400 all the way to 8000 shards to craft and you only get 10 to 20 shards per card scrap that's just unsightly and plain bad. It's very demoralizing and I find no way to be able to surmount to those costs anytime in the near future. Really demoralizes me and makes me feel shafted. And another tournament costs. 12000 CP to enter a tournament? really? A card pack costs 2000 CP already, which i believe is a fair price, but 12000 is way steep. That takes DAYS of saving for (this is my immediate impression, correct me if im wrong) ALL players, especially newer ones where they will easily feel their CP is better spent on packs. I have no way to try out new cards and feel out decks and know what i cards i want in teh future if i cant play in tourneys. Not to mention tourney's are the only place in the current game where you can play on fair footing with everyone.

But I digress, I have fallen in love with the game. I really like it. But in the end I feel like it's a great game with a couple BIG flaws. I plan to keep playing, and I want to get into it and try hard and be good at it, but I just feel it's a little impossible at this stage for me. I do recommend it to anyone who will play casually and not care about being competitive. Would advise those looking to be competitive that to be satisfied you'll either need to drop a good bit of cash (because ten dollars won't cut it) or pray and wait for game changes.
